pullRequest.body:
Define auxiliary polynomials for the secant-and-tangent negation `neg` and addition `add` on `Fin 3 -> F`. Note that the group operations are defined from scratch instead of pulling back the group operations from the affine case, as this will be more convenient for rewriting and allows them to be defined over a ring. I don't see an easy way to define an analogous `slope` function as in `Affine` when there are now `Z`-coordinates in the polynomials.

This is the second in a series of four PRs leading to #8485 

---

using the following format:

- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]
-->

maintainer merge
ðŸš€ Pull request has been placed on the maintainer queue by kbuzzard.

:v: Multramate can now approve this pull request. To approve and merge a pull request, simply reply with `bors r+`. More detailed instructions are available [here](https://bors.tech/documentation/getting-started/#reviewing-pull-requests).

> Can you add a bit of docstring at the beginning of the file explaining where to find the formulas?

I obtained the formulas in the `def`s by copying the output from Sage. I don't believe they're found in any online references. The polynomials I gave Sage are exactly those coming from affine coordinates but with denominators being cleared.

I will give a more thorough explanation in a future documentation PR when I split this file into multiple files.

bors r+

Build failed (retrying...):
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/10943821820/job/30384214490)

It looks like this needs to be updated for the recent changes in `linear_combination`. Please merge `master`, fix the build, and put this back on the queue. Thanks!

Canceled.
bors r+

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/10946645059/job/30393626141)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/10946645059/job/30393626395)

LGTM, thanks!

Can you add a bit of docstring at the beginning of the file explaining where to find the formulas?

bors d+

This is a stellar effort, well done. I think the large formulae are inevitable; formulae for addition and doubling are typically presented in the textbooks for curves of the form y^2=x^3+Ax+B but because you're (correctly) doing the general case I think it's inevitable that large formulae will appear.

LGTM, thanks!

Can you add a bit of docstring at the beginning of the file explaining where to find the formulas?

bors d+

**[imports]** reported by [reviewdog](https://github.com/reviewdog/reviewdog) :dog:
```suggestion import Mathlib.AlgebraicGeometry.EllipticCurve.Jacobian import Mathlib.AlgebraicGeometry.EllipticCurve.Projective ```
There are now two `hP`s. Isn't that a bit confusing? Or is it intentional?
Probably fine? The first `hP` doesn't appear inside the `have`, and the second `hP` doesn't appear outside the `have`.

This lemma really confused me, because it's not true that the Z coordinate of P+P is zero. Maybe add a docstring explaining that `addZ` is only valid for distinct points and so this lemma is just explaining a junk value, and that one should use `dblZ` instead when the points are the same? (assuming that's what's going on!)
Thanks, I will add this to the definition of `addZ`.

Maybe somewhere (docstring? module docstring?) it should be mentioned that `X_eq` means "X coordinates of P and Q are equal once normalised by dividing by Z coordinates"? Or maybe not -- I guess I just figured this out by looking at the statement.
I will remember to add these into the module docstrings when I refactor them into a separate file.

I think "negated addition" sounds a bit weird/complicated. Maybe just say "negated addition `-(P+Q)` of two distinct..." if that's what it is? This time it's impossible to tell from the code :-) Maybe also say that this produces a junk value of 0 if P=Q?
Sure, I will add this.
Do you understand why you need `erw` here whereas for most of the PR `rw` has been fine?

Yeah this is interesting. I really try to avoid `erw` whenever possible, but there are a couple of instances where I need to rewrite something like `a * ![0, 1, 0] 2`, and it's just faster to `erw [mul_zero]` to rewrite `a * 0 = ...`, rather than say `rw [Matrix.cons_val_two, Matrix.tail_cons, Matrix.head_cons, mul_zero]`.

This lemma is similar, but instead I need to rewrite `W.negY ![a, b, c] / c` using a lemma that says `W.negY ![a, b, c] / ![a, b, c] 2 = ...`, which avoids the matrix simp lemmas.

In all of these definitions I would add "returns a junk value if P=Q" just to be clear that this is what's happening (I was confused at first when reviewing this PR, so maybe others will be confused when reading it). My confusion stems from the fact that I was incorrectly assuming that in projective coordinates you can get away with one formula for addition, but apparently this is not correct. I guess that in affine coordinates there are many formulae (P+0, P+P, 0+P, P+(-P) etc) so presumably there are still gains to be had with two formulae.
Yeah, thanks! I will add this too.
Why not just `add` but in the appropriate namespace so people know it's an elliptic curve add?

This is not the addition of points, rather the resulting tuple of the addition of point representatives, which is mathematically correct if and only if the two points are distinct, so it doesn't deserve its own namespace. There will be a `def add (P Q : Fin 3 â†’ R) : Fin 3 â†’ R := if P â‰ˆ Q then W'.dblXYZ P else W'.addXYZ P Q` in an upcoming PR that addresses the issue of two points being distinct, and there will be a `def Point.add (P Q : W.Point) : W.Point` in a subsequent PR that is actually the addition of two elliptic curve points.
You can write `variable {P Q : Fin 3 â†’ F}`

Some of these only require the ring to be commutative (possibly with `NoZeroDivisors`), while others need the ring to be a field, so I thought the variables `P` and `Q` should be instantiated along with the lemma.
Same as above.

I wonder why you don't take out a `(P y - W'.negY P)` factor as before?
The simplest expression I could get for `dblX` is the factor times
```
(a1^2  x^3 + 3  a2  x^3 + a1  x^2  y + x  y^2 + a1^2  a2  x^2  z + 
  4  a2^2  x^2  z - a1  a3  x^2  z - 3  a4  x^2  z - a1^3  x  y  z - 
  4  a1  a2  x  y  z + a3  x  y  z - a1^2  y^2  z - 4  a2  y^2  z - 
  2  a3^2  x  z^2 + a1^2  a4  x  z^2 + 4  a2  a4  x  z^2 - 
  9  a6  x  z^2 - a1^2  a3  y  z^2 - 4  a2  a3  y  z^2 - 
  a2  a3^2  z^3 + a1  a3  a4  z^3 + a4^2  z^3)
```
which is yours plus `9 a3 x` times `W'.polynomial`.

Yeah that was the original expression that I called `preDblX` (and `preAddX` for addition). I thought that since we're already having massive polynomials, might as well write them out in full. Is there a use for `preDblX` by itself?
Well your `dblZ` is still in factored form. Why not factor `dblX` as well to make it shorter?

Better: the cubic factor in `dblX` can be replaced by 
```
-a2 x^3 + a1 x^2 y + x y^2 - a1 a3 x^2 z - 3 a4 x^2 z + a3 x y z - 
 2 a3^2 x z^2 - 9 a6 x z^2 - a2 a3^2 z^3 + a1 a3 a4 z^3 + a4^2 z^3 - 
 a1^2 a6 z^3 - 4 a2 a6 z^3
```
which is
`x polynomialY^2 - Ïˆhâ‚ƒ/z - 3 (x/z) polynomial`.
Now trying to do the same for `negDblY` ...

Note to myself: 
`z^2  (negDblY - y polynomialY^3 - c1 polynomialY) + polynomialX^3 = c2 polynomial`,
where
```
c1 = -3  a1^2  x^2  y - 12 a1 x y^2 - 18 y^3 - a1 a2^2 x^2 z + 
 3 a1 a4 x^2 z - 4 a2^2 x y z - 6 a1 a3 x y z + 12 a4 x y z + 
 a1^3 y^2 z + 5 a1 a2 y^2 z - 27 a3 y^2 z - 2 a2^2 a3 x z^2 + 
 6 a3 a4 x z^2 + 4 a1 a2 a3 y z^2 - 9 a3^2 y z^2 - 2 a1^2 a4 y z^2 - 
 2 a2 a4 y z^2 + 18 a6 y z^2 - a2 a3 a4 z^3 + a1 a4^2 z^3 - 
 3 a1 a2 a6 z^3 + 9 a3  a6  z^3
c2 = 3 (9 x^3 + 9 a2 x^2 z + 9 y^2 z - a1^2 a2 x z^2 + 3 a1 a3 x z^2 - 
   2 a1 a2 y z^2 + 12 a3 y z^2 - a1 a2 a3 z^3 + 3 a3^2 z^3)
```

Originally I worked out this formula in order to show when you apply `negDblY` to a 2-torsion nonsingular point (`polynomialY = 0` but `polynomialX â‰  0`) then `negDblY â‰  0`, so our doubling formula still holds in the P+P=O case. Now, with my accidental discovery that `negDblY` can be taken to be `Y polynomialY^3 + Ïˆhâ‚ƒ polynomialX` we can give an alternative proof: at a 2-torsion nonsingular point P â‰  O we have `Ïˆhâ‚ƒ â‰  0` because otherwise P is also 3-torsion and therefore P = O; since polynomialY=0 and polynomialXâ‰ 0 we conclude negDblYâ‰ 0. This is a bit circular though, as it uses a high-powered result #13782, even though the PR uses only Jacobian API which is independent of the projective case we consider here.

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat(AlgebraicGeometry/EllipticCurve/Projective): implement group operation polynomials for projective coordinates

source.title: feat(AlgebraicGeometry/EllipticCurve/Projective): implement group operations on point representatives for projective coordinates
feat(AlgebraicGeometry/EllipticCurve/Projective): implement group operations on nonsingular rational points for projective coordinates
feat(AlgebraicGeometry/EllipticCurve/Projective): implement group law for projective coordinates
[Merged by Bors] - feat(AlgebraicGeometry/EllipticCurve/Jacobian): implement group operation polynomials for Jacobian coordinates

source.title: feat(EllipticCurve): ZSMul formula in terms of division polynomials
